p.content: There are two types of questions: those which require a “Yes” or “No” answer and those which are seeking information. This section considers the main clause and embedded clause varieties of Yes/No questions and content questions, beginning with Yes/No questions.

In English, main clause Yes/No questions are formed by moving an auxiliary verb in front of the subject. Other languages use a Yes/No question marker or special complementizer instead of the fronted auxiliary. This is the case in embedded Yes/No questions in English; no auxiliary fronting is allowed but
or
fills the complementizer position. Since languages may act differently in main clause and embedded clause Yes/No questions, each will be covered separately.
English examples of main clause Yes/No questions, showing the required fronting of an auxiliary, include:
p.langData: Are you going to the store?
Will Sue buy the present for her mother?
p.content: and
p.langData: Could the boy have hit the ball?

p.content: In
main clause Yes/No questions,

case.caseText: there is no marker or word order change, just a difference in intonation or tone or other non-syntactic marking.
movement of an auxiliary
there is at least one question marker or complementizer.

case.caseText: written as a separate word.
is a clitic which attaches
at the edge of the question.
to the verb in the question.
These clitics are proclitics.
These clitics are enclitics.
There are some question marker or complementizer clitics which are proclitics and some which are enclitics.

All of the question markers or complementizers can occur on either side of the question.
There are restrictions as to which of the question markers or complementizers can occur on each side of the question.

p.content: examples of main clause Yes/No questions include:
English examples of Yes/No questions in embedded clauses, showing the presence of the question markers or complementizers, include:
p.langData: I wonder whether she will come
I will know if she goes
p.content: and
p.langData: Sue wonders whether the boy could have hit the ball

embedded clause Yes/No questions,

case.caseText: there is no marker or word order change, just a difference in intonation or tone or other non-syntactic marking.

p.content: examples of embedded clause Yes/No questions include:
Content questions differ from Yes/No questions in that they contain an interrogative word or phrase, known as wh-phrases in English because they almost all begin with
. In some languages, some or all of these interrogatives are expressed as affixes. The corresponding interrogative words or phrases or affixes in
are shown in the following chart.
Of the examples of interrogative words in table
, most simply stand alone as pronouns or adverbs, but
can either be a manner adverb by itself or a degree word modifying an adjective, as in
can either be a pronoun by itself or a demonstrative modifying a noun, as in
never stands alone but always modifies a noun as a demonstrative, as in
is a quantifier, as in
or
; and
can be either a stand alone possessive pronoun, or it can fill the possessor position in a nominal phrase, as in
These same possibilities are assumed to be true in
also.

text.content: Demonstratives are allowed on either side of the noun in
. The words meaning ‘which’ and ‘what’ occur

case.caseText: only before the noun, even if another demonstrative occurs after the noun.
only after the noun, even if another demonstrative occurs before the noun.
on either side of the noun, but when there is a demonstrative on each side at the same time, they must agree in features (e.g. both be interrogative words or both not be).

text.content: Articles are allowed on either side of the noun in
. The words meaning ‘which’ and ‘what’ occur

case.caseText: only before the noun, even if another article occurs after the noun.
only after the noun, even if another article occurs before the noun.
on either side of the noun, but when there is a article on each side at the same time, they must agree in features (e.g. both be interrogative words or both not be).

text.content: Degree words are allowed on either side of the adjective in
. The word meaning ‘how’ occurs

case.caseText: only before the adjective, even if another degree word occurs after the adjective.
only after the adjective, even if another degree word occurs before the adjective.
on either side of the adjective, but when there is a degree word on each side at the same time, they must agree in features (e.g. both be interrogative words or both not be).

text.content: Degree words are allowed on either side of the quantifier in
. The word meaning ‘how’ occurs

case.caseText: only before the quantifier, even if another degree word occurs after the quantifier.
only after the quantifier, even if another degree word occurs before the quantifier.
on either side of the quantifier, but when there is a degree word on each side at the same time, they must agree in features (e.g. both be interrogative words or both not be).

p.content: Depending on the basic word order of the language, content questions may be formed with or without fronting an interrogative phrase. Head-final languages (SOV, OVS, and OSV) usually do not have movement of an interrogative phrase in content questions, while head-initial languages (SVO, VOS, and VSO) usually require fronting of an interrogative phrase.

In languages without fronting for interrogatives, the phrase structure of a content question will either be the same as a Yes/No question with a question marker or auxiliary in the complementizer position or just the same as a normal sentence. In either case, the interrogative phrase appears in its normal argument positon. Many SOV languages optionally allow movement of an interrogative phrase to the position immediately before the verb.
In both main clause and embedded content questions in
, an interrogative phrase

case.caseText: does not front; it simply remains in place.
may remain in place or it may move to the position immediately before the verb.
moves to the front of the clause.

p.content: Main clause content questions in English require an interrogative phrase to be fronted and also have an auxiliary move to the position directly after the fronted interrogrative phrase when something other than the subject is being questioned. Some examples of English main clause content questions are:
p.langData: Who might have hit the ball?
p.content: and

p.content: examples of main clause content questions include:

In English embedded content questions, an interrogative phrase is required to be fronted to the beginning of the embedded clause. However, in contrast to the main clause content questions, there is no auxiliary fronting. Examples of English embedded content questions include:
p.langData: I know who hit the ball
I wonder when she will come
p.content: and
p.langData: I will ask what the boy hit
